content.description: A mental health condition characterized by an uninterrupted period of illness featuring concurrent symptoms of schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech/behavior, negative symptoms) and major mood episodes (major depressive or manic).
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Uninterrupted period of illness during which there is a major mood episode (depressive or manic) concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia. B. Delusions or hallucinations for 2 or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode during the lifetime duration of the illness. C. Symptoms meeting criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the active and residual portions of the illness. D. Not attributable to the effects of a substance or another medical condition.
content.prevalence: Lifetime prevalence estimated at 0.3%; less common than schizophrenia but more common than bipolar disorder with psychotic features.
content.age_of_onset: Typically emerges in late adolescence to early adulthood, similar to schizophrenia and bipolar disorder onset patterns.
content.prognosis: Intermediate between schizophrenia and mood disorders. Better than schizophrenia if mood symptoms are responsive to treatment, but worse than mood disorders alone. Chronic impairment possible without sustained treatment.

circuitry: Abnormalities in prefrontal-limbic-striatal circuits affecting mood regulation and psychotic processing.
neurochemistry: Dopaminergic hyperactivity during psychotic episodes; serotonergic and glutamatergic dysregulation linked to mood symptoms.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Increased familial risk for both schizophrenia and bipolar disorder; environmental triggers include stress, trauma, and substance use.

history_psychosocial: Timeline of psychotic and mood symptoms to establish periods of independence and overlap.
medical_assessment: Screen for neurological and endocrine causes.
risk_stratification: Suicide risk highest during depressive or mixed episodes.
Assess risk of aggression during psychosis or mania.
differential_diagnosis: Bipolar I/II disorder with psychotic features
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
evaluation.team_and_process: Integrated psychiatric and psychosocial assessment with longitudinal monitoring.

severity_levels.mild: Mild psychotic and mood symptoms with minimal functional impairment.
severity_levels.moderate: Persistent symptoms impacting work/school and relationships.
severity_levels.severe: Severe psychotic and mood symptoms with high relapse risk, poor insight, and significant disability.

biological: Family history of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder

impact_on_life.school_work: Difficulty sustaining performance due to relapses and residual symptoms.
impact_on_life.social: Strained relationships from unpredictable mood and behavior changes.
impact_on_life.medical: Side effects from long-term psychotropic medication use.

medications: Antidepressants for depressive episodes (with caution for manic switching)
neuromodulation: ECT for severe depression or treatment-resistant mania with psychosis
care_coordination: Integrated psychiatric and psychosocial rehabilitation services

treatment_goals: Achieve remission of both psychotic and mood symptoms.
Improve functioning and quality of life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Assuming mood symptoms are always secondary to psychosis without identifying independent episodes.
Mislabeling as bipolar disorder or schizophrenia without full longitudinal history.
overdiagnosis_factors: Diagnosing based on transient mood symptoms during psychosis without meeting duration criteria.
Confusing schizoaffective disorder with brief psychotic disorder plus mood symptoms.

specifiers.bipolar_type: Manic episode is part of presentation; may have depressive episodes.

warning_signs: New-onset psychosis with mood instability lasting weeks to months.
Periods of psychosis without concurrent mood symptoms.
self_help_strategies: Medication adherence with regular psychiatric follow-up.
Early recognition of relapse warning signs.

adolescents: Mood lability with emerging psychotic symptoms; decline in school performance.
adults: Work impairment, social withdrawal, alternating periods of mood elevation and depression with psychosis.
older_adults: May present with more affective symptoms and less florid psychosis.

real_life_examples: A 24-year-old experiences auditory hallucinations and paranoia alongside manic episodes; later has 3 weeks of persistent hallucinations without mood symptoms, confirming schizoaffective disorder bipolar type.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek immediate evaluation for psychosis, suicidal thoughts, or dangerous behavior. Early treatment improves prognosis.
